description: Kohlrabi is a unique vegetable that belongs to the Brassica family, which also includes cabbage, broccoli, and kale. It is prized for its bulbous stem, which has a crisp texture and a mild, sweet flavor reminiscent of cabbage and turnip. Kohlrabi can be eaten raw or cooked and is commonly used in salads, stir-fries, soups, and slaws.
varieties: Kohlrabi, a member of the cabbage family, comes in several varieties, each with its unique characteristics and culinary uses. Common varieties of kohlrabi include 'Early White Vienna', known for its pale green skin and tender flesh; 'Purple Vienna', recognized for its vibrant purple skin and slightly sweeter flavor; and 'Kolibri', prized for its purple-and-white bi-colored skin. These varieties offer a range of options suited for different culinary preferences and growing conditions.

sowingAndPlanting.sowingIndoorsDescription: Kohlrabi seeds can be started indoors 4-6 weeks before the last frost date. Plant seeds in pots or trays filled with seed-starting mix. Sow seeds 1/4 to 1/2 inch deep and keep the soil consistently moist and cool (60-70°F). Provide bright, indirect light or use grow lights to encourage healthy seedling growth. Transplant seedlings outdoors after the danger of frost has passed and the soil has warmed up.
sowingAndPlanting.sowingOutdoorsDescription: Kohlrabi seeds can also be directly sown outdoors once the soil has warmed up and all danger of frost has passed. Choose a sunny location with well-drained soil. Plant seeds 1/4 to 1/2 inch deep and space them 4-6 inches apart in rows spaced 12-18 inches apart. Keep the soil consistently moist until seedlings emerge.
sowingAndPlanting.season: Kohlrabi can be planted in both spring and fall. For spring planting, sow seeds as soon as the soil can be worked. For fall planting, sow seeds 6-8 weeks before the first expected frost date.

careAndMaintenance.growingDescription: Kohlrabi prefers full sun to partial shade and well-drained soil rich in organic matter. It requires regular watering to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. Mulch around plants to conserve moisture, suppress weeds, and maintain even soil temperature.
careAndMaintenance.wateringNeeds: Regular watering, aiming for 1-2 inches per week.
careAndMaintenance.soilFertility: Incorporate compost or well-aged manure into the soil before planting to improve fertility and soil structure. Side-dress kohlrabi with a balanced fertilizer once it starts growing.
careAndMaintenance.pruningRequirements: Kohlrabi generally does not require pruning. However, you can remove any yellowing or damaged leaves as needed to improve air circulation and aesthetics.
careAndMaintenance.supportRequirements: Kohlrabi typically does not require support.

harvestingAndStorage.timeToMaturity: Kohlrabi typically matures and is ready for harvest 45-60 days after planting, depending on the variety and growing conditions.
harvestingAndStorage.storageRecommendations: Harvest kohlrabi when the bulb reaches the desired size, usually 2-3 inches in diameter. Use a sharp knife to cut the bulb just above the soil surface. Wash harvested kohlrabi thoroughly to remove any dirt or debris. Store kohlrabi in the refrigerator for up to a week, loosely wrapped in a damp paper towel or plastic bag to maintain moisture.
harvestingAndStorage.harvestDescription: Harvest kohlrabi by cutting the bulb just above the soil surface with a sharp knife. Leave the leaves attached to the bulb, as they can be eaten as well.

goodCompanionPlants.name: Beets
goodCompanionPlants.description: Beets and kohlrabi are both cool-season crops with similar cultural requirements. Interplanting them can help maximize space in the garden and reduce competition for soil nutrients. Additionally, beets can act as a living mulch to help suppress weeds and conserve soil moisture for kohlrabi.

goodCompanionPlants.name: Lettuce
goodCompanionPlants.description: Lettuce has shallow roots and grows well in the shade of taller plants like kohlrabi. Interplanting lettuce with kohlrabi can help conserve soil moisture, suppress weeds, and provide living mulch to cool the soil, creating a beneficial microclimate for both crops.

goodCompanionPlants.name: Onions
goodCompanionPlants.description: Onions and kohlrabi are compatible companions. Interplanting onions with kohlrabi can help deter pests such as cabbage worms and aphids, which commonly affect brassica crops like kohlrabi. Additionally, onions can help suppress weeds and improve soil health.

goodCompanionPlants.name: Potatoes
goodCompanionPlants.description: Potatoes and kohlrabi can be grown together as companion plants. Kohlrabi's shallow roots and compact growth habit make it compatible with potatoes, allowing them to coexist without competing for space or nutrients. Additionally, kohlrabi can help suppress weeds and improve soil structure for potatoes.

goodCompanionPlants.name: Spinach
goodCompanionPlants.description: Spinach is a cool-season crop that complements kohlrabi well. Interplanting spinach with kohlrabi can help maximize space in the garden and provide mutual benefits, such as weed suppression and soil moisture conservation. Additionally, spinach can be harvested early, allowing more space and resources for kohlrabi as it matures.

badCompanionPlants.name: Strawberries
badCompanionPlants.description: Strawberries and kohlrabi are not ideal companions. While they can grow in the same garden bed, planting them too closely together may result in competition for nutrients and space, leading to reduced yields for both crops. Additionally, strawberries may attract pests that can damage kohlrabi plants.

badCompanionPlants.name: Beans
badCompanionPlants.description: Beans and kohlrabi may compete for similar soil nutrients, especially if planted too closely together. Additionally, beans may attract pests like aphids and bean beetles, which can also affect kohlrabi plants. It's best to avoid planting beans near kohlrabi.

badCompanionPlants.name: Brassicas
badCompanionPlants.description: Kohlrabi belongs to the brassica family, and planting it near other brassicas like cabbage, broccoli, and kale may increase the risk of pest and disease problems. Cross-contamination of pests and diseases can occur more easily when brassicas are grown in close proximity.

badCompanionPlants.name: Sunflower
badCompanionPlants.description: Sunflowers have dense root systems that may compete with kohlrabi for water and nutrients. Planting them together may result in reduced growth and yield for kohlrabi crops. Additionally, sunflowers may cast shade on kohlrabi plants, affecting their growth and development.

badCompanionPlants.name: Fennel
badCompanionPlants.description: Fennel contains compounds that can inhibit the growth of nearby plants, including kohlrabi. Planting kohlrabi near fennel may result in stunted growth and reduced yield for kohlrabi crops. It's best to keep them separate in the garden.

tipsAndTricks: Plant kohlrabi in well-drained soil with full sun to partial shade exposure.
Space kohlrabi plants properly to allow good air circulation.
Water kohlrabi regularly, keeping the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged.
Mulch around the base of plants to retain moisture and suppress weeds.
Harvest kohlrabi bulbs when they are young and tender, typically when they reach 2-3 inches in diameter.
Rotate crops to prevent the buildup of pests and diseases in the soil.
Monitor plants regularly for signs of pests and diseases, and take appropriate action.
